title: Is the reclaiming of H1B bound by time frame? I.e. is it necessary to reclaim within a year?
question: I was in US for a year on H1B (Feb 2004-Feb2005). I visited US again in 2009 on Dependent (H4). Would it be possible to reclaim the 5 years on the previous H1 without being subject to the cap?
answers: Actually, I have a different view to the last 2 posters. Assuming that you were outside the US for one full year since you held H-1B status, I believe that you have the choice of (a) reclaiming the reminder of your H-1B time; or (b) restarting the 6-years and being subject to the cap. There is a memo from Michael Aytes, CIS, dated 12/5/06 that specifically addresses this scenario.
Mr. Reich is correct. If an employee is out of the U.S. for a year, they must re-apply for an H1-b. This means that time on an expired H1-b1 cannot be reclaimed.

Not exactly, though it doesn't sound like you will be able to reclaim unused time in your case.

H-1B time re-sets once you have spent a full year overseas (our of the U.S.) Since you have apparently been out of the U.S. for over a year, you will need to go through the H-1B lottery again for a new six-year H-1B period.

However, had you been here for the five years since February 2005 in some other status, you WOULD gave been able to go back to H-1B status for the remaining five years even though fivee years had passed, because you had not left for a year.

It isn't only the time, it is where you spend the time.

No you can always reclaim the 5 years. If you want to reclaim fresh then you have to be outside for one year.

Good Luck
